signature.instructions:
Task: Answer the question using only facts from the provided English context, returning a minimal Yoruba answer.

Input format:
- question_lang: the question text (typically in Yoruba).
- context: an English passage that contains the answer.

Output format:
- Return only the final answer string in Yoruba (same language as the question).
- No labels, no reasoning, no explanations, no punctuation. No extra words or spaces.
- No leading/trailing spaces or newlines.

Core rules:
1) Source of truth:
   - Use only facts explicitly stated or directly entailed by the context.
   - If the context does not contain the answer, reply exactly: ko si ninu akoonu
     • All lowercase, no extra characters or spaces.
   - Never guess or use outside knowledge.

2) Yes/No questions:
   - Yoruba yes/no questions often start with “ṣe” or “Ṣe”.
   - Answer with exactly one word:
     • Yes → bẹẹni
     • No → rara
   - Only use bẹẹni/rara if the context supports a definite yes/no.
   - If the context does not confirm either way, reply: ko si ninu akoonu

3) Year questions:
   - If the question starts with “Odun wo ni …” or “Ọdun wo ni …”, reply: Ọdun YYYY
     • Use the dotted capital Ọ exactly: Ọdun 1947
   - If the question uses “Ni ọdun wo …”, reply with the 4-digit year only: YYYY
   - If the question asks a general “when” (e.g., “Nigbawo…”, “Igba wo ni…”):
     • Return the most specific date stated in the context:
       - If day–month–year is given: D Month YYYY (with Yoruba month name)
       - If only month–year is given: Month YYYY
       - If only year is given: Ọdun YYYY
   - Match the question pattern strictly even if the context contains more detailed dates.

4) Counts and numbers:
   - For “mẹlo”, “melo”, “meloo”, “melooo” type questions: return digits only (Arabic numerals), no words or units. Example: 58
   - Use digits for any numeric answer when the question asks “how many” or expects a count.

5) Names, places, and phrasing:
   - Preserve proper names exactly as in the context (e.g., “Herbert Stein”, “United Kingdom”, “Westminster Abbey”).
   - Keep answers as short as possible; if a single proper name or place suffices, return only that.
   - Use minimal Yoruba relational phrasing only if needed to form the direct answer (e.g., “apa guusu ti Westminster Abbey” when a relational location is explicitly required).

6) Dates and Yoruba month names:
   - When rendering months in Yoruba, use these names exactly (with diacritics):
     • January → Sẹ́rẹ́
     • February → Èrèlè
     • March → Ẹrẹ̀nà
     • April → Ìgbé
     • May → Èbìbí
     • June → Òkúdu
     • July → Agẹmọ
     • August → Ògún
     • September → Owewe
     • October → Ọ̀wàrà
     • November → Bélú
     • December → Ọpẹ́
   - Day format: D Month YYYY (no ordinals, no commas). Example: 11 Ọpẹ́ 2021

7) Minimality and precision:
   - Return only the shortest phrase that directly answers the question.
   - Do not restate the question or add qualifiers.
   - Maintain correct casing; Yoruba generic words in lower case; proper names as in the context.
   - Do not translate proper names; translate generic category words only if essential (e.g., “ipinlẹ Niger” for “Niger State”).

Quality checks before answering:
- Confirm the answer is explicitly in the context; otherwise output exactly: ko si ninu akoonu
- For yes/no, ensure the polarity is supported by the context; otherwise: ko si ninu akoonu
- For year questions, ensure the format matches the question’s pattern exactly:
  • “Odun wo ni …” or “Ọdun wo ni …” → Ọdun YYYY
  • “Ni ọdun wo …” → YYYY
  • General “when” → most specific date (D Month YYYY > Month YYYY > Ọdun YYYY)
- Verify Yoruba month mapping is correct (e.g., January = Sẹ́rẹ́, December = Ọpẹ́).
- No punctuation, no extra words, no extra spaces.

Examples (formatting only; do not include explanations in outputs):
- Q: “Odun wo ni a bi Victor Malu?” with context “born on 15 January 1947 …”
  → Output: Ọdun 1947
- Q: “Nigbawo ni a bi Victor Malu?” with same context
  → Output: 15 Sẹ́rẹ́ 1947
- Q: “Tani baba to bi Benjamin Jeremy?” with context stating “Stein is the son of … Herbert Stein”
  → Output: Herbert Stein
- Q: “ṣe ijoba United Kingdom fowosi ikọsile?” with unrelated context
  → Output: ko si ninu akoonu
